title: banning huawei from uks 5g network is a good day for britain and a great day for freedom
story: People must be under no illusion: Huawei is to all intents and purposes a Chinese state company.Nothing that the company does can go against the Chinese Communist Partythat rules that state.And given this fact, it was not just wrong but reckless of the UK to even think of having the company involved in the creation of our sensitive networks.Now we will inevitably pay more for G as costs rise by £billion — and we will have to wait a further two to three years for it to be rolled out. Of course, whatever the cost becomes, it is less than the cost of the threat to our national security and is a price we must pay. We were warned repeatedly by all of our allies about involving Huawei in our communications network.In recent years, I have heard first-hand from each of our intelligence-sharing partners in the so-called “Five Eyes” network . All of these countries, our closest allies, have been deeply worried by Britain’s decision. All have warned that this country — and our relationships with our allies — would be compromisedwe allowed Huawei such access. We would have been vulnerable, they warned.Bizarrely, Theresa May ignored this advice, then Boris Johnson’s government originally went further down this terrible road.This, despite the fact that other companies — including US firms — could have provided just the same technology, without the same security risks.And, key sources tell me, all for the same price. Still the Government snubbed our allies, alarmed our friends, and stuck to their decision.Privately it was briefed out that our own security services were confident of their ability to get backdoor access to see what Huawei would be doing and to control any covert activity. But all of this seemed a ridiculously high-risk venture. And for what exactly  Fortunately, that bizarre decision got reversed yesterday.Several factors have contributed to it. The first is an obvious change in relations towards China that is going on around the world. Covid- has played a part. China — unwittingly or carelessly — gave the world a virus which has all but halted our economies.The CCP’s lies and cover-ups during this devastating period have meant that all of us have been confined to our houses for months — and not just those who have contracted the coronavirus that came from Wuhan.In the months and years ahead, all of us will be poorer because of the CCP’s lies. The state has disappeared its own scientists. It allowed travel even after it knew what it was dealing with. It lied about the nature of the virus.And other members of the Five Eyes network have suggested that the evidence points clearly to the virus having been created in a Chinese laboratory.President Trump and his Secretary of State, Mike Pompeo, have rightly made an issue of this. Both have been warning for years about the instability of China as a partner. As recent events in Hong Kong should remind us, China is a one-party, totalitarian state. It rules by dictatorship and terror. Of course, it is also highly technologically skilled and financially ever more dominant.The CCP seeks to make China the world’s leading power. Washington is — rightly — determined to stop that. And this country —we value freedom and the rule of law, as we always have — should seek to stop that too.This means, among much , denying China and Chinese state companies from extending their grip in countries like ours.For years, Chinese companies have stolen information, ripped off s, and otherwise acted completely unlawfully. They have engaged in espionage and information theft on an industrial scale.Some people might look at yesterday’s decision and think it a small, technical matter. It isn’t.Not only is it a decision with far-reaching consequences for this country’s security. It is also a signal of which side this country will be on in one of the most important tussles of our day.Everywhere China seeks to extend its power is an area where freedom recedes.Yesterday was a bad day for Huawei, a good day for Britain and a great day for freedom.Q: WHAT is the new ruling on Huawei A: From the end of this year, telecoms firms will not be able to buy any new Huawei hardware, such as antennas, to put into their G networks. By the end of , all Huawei equipment must be stripped out of the UK’s G networks.Q: Why is G important A: It will be ten times faster than G and allow more complicated technology, such as driverless cars, to operate.Q: What is Huawei currently used for A: The firm is the leading provider of technology needed to operate wireless networks that provide the G signal on our mobile phones. They were going to be used for “non-core” equipment in the G network. Instead European firms Nokia or Erion are likely to provide the hardware.Q: Can I still use my Huawei mobile phone A: Yes. There is no plan to ban its handsets.Q: Will the ban affect my phone signal A: Some telecom firms have warned that stripping out all Huawei hardware too quickly could result in a temporary loss of signal in some places, but other experts say this concern has been exaggerated.Q: Does this affect full fibre broadband connections A: Not at the moment. The Government’s security advisers have only recommended “transitioning away” from Huawei when it comes to fibre networks.Q: Will I have to replace a Huawei router in my home A: The router is not part of the G infrastructure and won’t be affected.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: wear a mask to the shops its not a big deal
story: The moaning over their compulsory use in shops from next Friday is ridiculous.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesSome pretend it is a grotesque assault on our civil liberties — a “monstrous imposition”, one daft Tory backbencher called it. It really isn’t. Nor will refusing to wear one make someone a hero. If their reluctance is just vanity or embarrassment, they should get over themselves. A mask’s main purpose is to protect ­others. That’s reason enough.That’s not to say we don’t have a few doubts. Health Secretary Matt Hancock says masks “give people more confidence to shop safely”. Well, perhaps. But one new survey indicates that half of families will be scared away from shopsthe Government really considers them that dangerous.We only hope they are vastly outnumbered by those who DO feel safer — or the new edict will strangle our feeble­-looking recovery instead of boosting it.Plus, we have to ask: when will the new rules end  Is there a plan The Government was farcically late imposing them. The Sun backed masks when there were , new UK Covid cases a day. It’s now a tenth of that and the risk of catching it very, very small. How low must daily infections be before we ditch masks . . .     Zero On balance, we still believe their routine use, along with social distancing and hand washing, are our three best forms of self-defence. For now.But normality mustrapidly or our economic prospects are unthinkably grim.  THOSE dire prospects are starkly exposed in the latest woeful economic data.It should be no surprise that growth saw only a slight uptick in May. Shops and pubs still weren’t open. Even so, a . per cent rise barely registers against the . per cent fall in March and April.There’s even worse news on jobs: unemployment is forecast to triple by Christmas, while our deficit hits a mind-boggling £billion for the year.We celebrated when Bank of England chief economist Andy Haldane said a swt V-shaped recovery was under way.We now wonder what he’s been smoking.FOR a decade Britain cosied up to a ­Chinese regime which has increasingly revealed itself to be malign.The belated Huawei U-turn must be just a first step in reversing that trend. story: Temperatures are set to rise to C tomorrow in parts of the UK, making it warmer than the sunny Spanish island. The mercury will start to climb from Thursday with C expected in London and the south east.A large plume of air is set to sweep across the continent towards the UK, bringing hot weather.On Thursday the Midlands will see highs of C and C in Wales and Scotland as a band of high pressure swirls over the UK.But along with the warmer temperatures some areas could see downpours as well.The north west is expected to be hit the hardest and the west forecasted to be largely cloudy.By Friday it could tip C - making it even hotter than Ibiza .And forecasters reckon the mini heatwave could last all weekend with C on Saturday and C on Sunday.All eyes will be on Bournemouth beach after thousands sparked a major incident at the end of last month.They crammed onto the sand for the hottest day of the year so far as temperatures sky-rocketed to a blistering .C.Since then the UK has been deprived of sun amid constant cloud cover and non-stop downpours.Figures compiled by the Met Office show the nation has seen just . hours of sunshine in the first half of this month.The average for the entire month is  hours.Met Office forecaster Nicky Maxey said: Its even lower in some regions.Derbyshire, for example, has only seen . hours of sunshine between July  and July .The county gets an average of  hours of sunshine so theyve only seen  per cent of what theyd normally have.Luckily, the sunshine is back over the next few days.Its going to feel more like July. title: one in three firms lay off staff furlough
story: The British Chamber of Commerce said that an historic cash crunch is pushing businesses to tighten up their budgets and let staff go as the country struggles to recover from the lockdown.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesAccording to poll done of , businesses by BCC and TotalJobs,  per cent of businesses expect they will have to make job cuts in the next three months - the highest number on record. The revelations stoke fears the Chancellors furlough scheme has only been masking widespread job losses in Britain.But as many as  per cent of businesses will keep their staff on after Rishi Sunak offered to pay £ for each furloughed worker that is brought back to work until at least January. Only  per cent of firms are looking to increase the size of their workforce.Mr Sunak extended the furlough scheme, but employers will need to start to make pension and national insurance contributions from next month. From September businesses will have to pay  per cent of their staffs wages, with the Government scaling back their support from  per cent to  per cent. By October they will be asked to pay  per cent with a  per cent contribution from the Government.The job losses will be felt most in bigger firms - around  per cent of large firms with over  employees expect to make lay offs, compared to  per cent of micro firms with fewer than  employees. The percentage of firms actively trying to bring on new employees dropped to the lowest level on record at  per cent. Since the lockdown began in March there are , fewer people in jobs, according to new figures by the ONS.The number of actual hours worked by employees between March and May this year was down by . million - or . per cent - to . million hours, the biggest drip since estimates began in . Business Secretary Alok Sharma said this morning: The figures out there, that is iniduals who will be finding it very dficult at this time. But he said the Treasurys coronavirus schemes - included the furlough scheme - has helped save jobs. He said: There is support out there. But I completely acknowledge this is going to be a very dficult time for lots of people out there who are facing a huge amount of worry.The job losses also makes the Governments challenge of getting to spend money on British restaurants, pubs and shops to bolster the economy all the more dficult. Boris Johnson is gearing up to announce his plan to get people back into offices and onto public transport to help people behave and spend more normally. The public will be advised to still avoid using public transport during peak rush hour times of -am, which will still be categorised as “essential travel only”.Instead the public will be told to use public transport outside of rush hours - between am and pm and after pm and encouraged to walk and cycleat all possible during peak times.A Whitehall source said: “We are looking at the messaging - it will look at grading the times people travel.“There is a lot of extra capacity on public transport that is not being used.“People will be told thatyou avoid the rush hour, the crush times, it is safe to travel.BCC Co-Executive Director Hannah Essex said: “Many businesses are suffering from an historic cash crunch and reduced demand, meaning firms will still face tough decisions despite welcome interventions made in the Summer Statement.“The government should consider additional support for employers before the Autumn Budget to reduce the overall cost of employment and prevent substantial redundancies.Measures could include a temporary cut in employer National Insurance Contributions and support to upskill and reskill employees as businesses adapt to change.”  Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: finger meat pie brazil
story: Victor Santos, , spat out the chopped off joint - which still had the nail intact - and screamed with horror before being physically sick following the discovery.The schoolboy’s parents said they ordered a selection of savoury pastries with assorted fillings for home delivery last Saturday from a local takeaway in São Paulo, Brazil.As they sat down to eat, the boy picked one of the pastries and, when he took his first bite, he found the severed finger in it.Eduardo do Carmo Santos, owner of the Companhia da Esfiha, apparently admitted to police that “one ofemployees cut off the top of his fore finger while slicing pepperoni.”The chef, named as Jesus de Souza Silva, , was allegedly using a meat slicer when the accident happened.Mr do Carmo Santos claimed: “ searched for his missing fingertip in the food, on the kitchen floor and in the equipment used to cut the pepperoni but couldn’t find it.“He was taken to hospital for emergency treatment and we closed the restaurant for a couple days.”Images show the pallid fingertip with the unbroken nail encased in shrivelled skin, after it was subjected to high temperatures in the oven.Cartilage and the ends of jagged bones can be seen from the underside of the severed finger.The takeaway - which produces a range of pizzas and savoury pastries - reopened on Saturday and began taking orders again without apparently reporting the work accident to the area’s health and safety authority.That same evening two officers, out on patrol, found the shocked family gathered outside the snack bar angrily demanding answers about the finger found in the food.The schoolboy’s distressed mum, Elisangela, , reportedly said in a statement to cops: “We ordered a box of esfihas by phone for home delivery. When it came my son picked out one of the pastries which is his favourite.“He took his first bite and found something strange, hard and fleshy in his mouth. He immediately spat it out because this is not the type of thing you would expect to find in an esfiha.“When we inspected it, we were horried to discover the piece was the top of a human finger.“My son was ill when he realised what had been in his mouth and that he had nearly swallowed it. He is totally shaken up and is suffering nightmares after this appalling experience.”A team of health and safety experts from the Consumer Protection Institute visited the takeaway within hours and ordered it to close following its apparent failure to meet acceptable hygiene standards and safety conditions.The owner faces substantial fines for inadequate consumer standards along with criminal charges of culpable bodily injury and endangering the health and le of a minor and worker.The evidence has been collected by the Institute of Forensic Medicine and is being examined as part of the criminal proceedings. The teenager’s mum said her son will never eat another meat pastry again.The family has been advised to take legal action and seek compensation against the restaurant for risking the teenager’s health and endangering his mental stability.The injured chef was taken to hospital and has already been discharged with remedial treatment continuing at home.The bakery has been contacted for a response.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: madeleine mccann suspect christian b release decision
story: Christian B left Germany in  for Italy, and was extradited back on a European Arrest Warrant for a drugs offence.Christian B, , is currently in jail serving  months for drug offences and last month was eligible for parole after serving two thirds of his sentence.In December he was convicted of raping a  year old American woman in  in her own home just a few minutes walk from where Maddie was taken two years later in Praia da Luz, Portugal.Today his lawyer Friedrich Fulscher argued that protocols in the use of the European Arrest Warrant were breached when Germany secured his extradition from Italy to Germany in .Mr Fulscher argued on a technicality that speciality protection lawwas broken because he was extradited for the drugs conviction but then subsequently put on trial for raping the elderly woman. Christian B was later sentenced to seven years for the rape but his legal team say he should not have been put on trial because Portugal was also not consulted over the use of the European Warrant.The case was adjourned until August  when the European Court of Justice will deliver an interim opinion before a later judgement.Mr Fulscher refused to answer questions from the media when the case ended.Last month Christian B was named as the prime suspect in the disappearance of three-year-old Maddie from Praia da Luz in .Mobile phone data showed he was in the Portuguese village at the time she vanished.Chief public prosecutor, Hans Christian Wolters, who is leading the investigation says the outcome of the ECJ hearing could result in his conviction being quashed.He said: “The defence seeks to have the rape conviction overturned by the Federal Court of Justice – Germany’s supreme court.“The defence can achieve thisthe ECJ considers Portugals consent to have been necessary.”Christian B, who will not appear in court today, will be informed of the decision in his jail cell in Kiel, northern Germany.Last month, The Sun reported how Christian B is being bullied behind bars over the case.His lawyer Mr Fulscher told German magazine Der Spiegel: “Fellow inmates try to bully him where they can.“He is pilloried worldwide and easily identiable.”Our title: russia documents corbyn
story: The Kremlin laughed off the allegations calling them “foggy and contradictory” after Downing Street announced that sensitive material relating to a UK-US trade deal was “almost certainly” spread by “Russian actors.”The former Labour leader had tried to use the leaked NHS documents used to smear the Tories ahead of his disastrous election result.They were first uploaded onto the internet site Reddit - but got no attention.Russian actors then sought to promote them further and get more media attention to try and interfere in the UKs election, the Government said.The Russian Embassy in London warned that any unfriendly actions will not be left without a proper and adequate response.The embassy said Moscow has not and will never interfere in the internal affairs of the UK and denied targeting efforts to develop a coronavirus vaccine.We have also taken note of the Foreign Secretarys suggestion that the UK Government reserves the right to respond with appropriate measures in the future, a statement said.In this regard, we would like to state once again that any unfriendly actions against Russia will not be left without a proper and adequate response.Russian foreign minister spokeswoman Maria Zakharova responded to the claims branding them anti-Russia nonsense.She said: The statement is so foggy and contradictory that its practically impossible to understand it.If it’s inappropriate to say something then dont say it. If you say it, produce the facts”.Today, Foreign Secretary Dominic Raab called the alleged interference unacceptable.He said: The Government has concluded that it is almost certain that Russian actors sought to interfere in the  General Election through the online amplication of illicitly acquired and leaked Government documents.Sensitive Government documents relating to the UK-US Free Trade Agreement were illicitly acquired before the  General Election and disseminated online via the social media  Reddit. When these gained no traction, further attempts were made to promote the illicitly acquired material online in the run up to the General Election.Whilst there is no evidence of a broad spectrum Russian campaign against the General Election, any attempt to interfere in our democratic processes is completely unacceptable. It is, and will always be, an absolute priority to protect our democracy and elections.The Government said today:There is an ongoing criminal investigation and it would be inappropriate for us to say anything further at this point.Mr Corbyn responded to the claims in a Facebook post calling the docs genuine.He said: The documents we revealed during the general election about the danger of a Trump trade deal for our NHS were genuine - as is the threat of a £ million a week higher drugs bill.The Tories want to distract from the damage a Trump trade deal would do to our NHS by continuing to push the bogus claim Labour received Russian support.Today’s government claim is an attempt to ert attention from the threat to the NHS and the Tory party links to Russian oligarchs expected to be revealed in the long-buried parliamentary Russia report.Mr Corbyn has been repeatedly accused of being soft on Russia, even refusing to blame them for the Salisbury Novichok attack.The ousted hard left Labour leader would only go as far as saying “the evidence points strongly” to the Kremlin.In March last year Mr Corbyn sparked a furious backlash after warning Theresa May against “rushing way ahead of the evidence” on Salisbury.His spokesman at the time said memories of the Iraqi “dodgy” dossier meant it was “problematic” to accept the Government’s position.Labour today distanced themselves from Russia.A spokesman said: “We condemn any attempt by Russia..to interfere in our country’s democratic processes. Labour stands ready to work cross-party to protect our nation’s security.It came on the same day the UK was able to point the finger at Russia for the very first time in explosive claims President Putin knew about attacks on Britains coronavirus vaccine project.A joint operation with the US and Canada has uncovered a malicious campaign to steal information uncovered by Britains top scientists on coronavirus with targeted attacks since March.No said today they believe the attacks came from a group known at APT - part of the Russian intelligence service.The clandestine group of hackers is also known as “the Dukes” or “Cozy Bear”.The PMs official spokesman said today: The attacks which are taking place against scientists and others doing vital work to combat coronavirus are despicable.Working with our allies, we will call out those who seek to do us harm in cyber space and hold them to account.I AM today updating Parliament on the ongoing investigations into the leak of the UK-US Free Trade Agreement documents ahead of the General Election in . The Chair of the Intelligence and Security Committee has been briefed on the details of this incident.The Government has robust systems in place to protect the UK against foreign malign influence. These bring together government, civil society and private sector organisations to monitor and respond to interference, to ensure our democracy stays open, transparent and resilient. During the  General Election a cross-Government election security cell was stood up to coordinate responses to threats and hazards relating to the election.On the basis of extensive analysis, the Government has concluded that it is almost certain that Russian actors sought to interfere in the  General Election through the online amplication of illicitly acquired and leaked Government documents.Sensitive Government documents relating to the UK-US Free Trade Agreement were illicitly acquired before the  General Election and disseminated online via the social media  Reddit. When these gained no traction, further attempts were made to promote the illicitly acquired material online in the run up to the General Election.Whilst there is no evidence of a broad spectrum Russian campaign against the General Election, any attempt to interfere in our democratic processes is completely unacceptable. It is, and will always be, an absolute priority to protect our democracy and elections.There is an ongoing criminal investigation and it would be inappropriate for us to say anything further at this point.The Government reserves the right to respond with appropriate measures in the future.The UK will continue to call out and respond to malign activity, including any attempts to interfere in our democratic processes, alongside our international partners. We fully support the recent action taken by our German partners who exposed Russian responsibility for the hack of their Parliament in  as well as their intention to act against those responsible under the cyber sanctions regime. The UK Government laid the statutory instrument for our own cyber sanctions regime on  June.The online forum Reddit confirmed the NHS leak was linked to the Kremlin in December last year.The dossier of leaked minutes from trade talks, which Mr Corbyn claimed was evidence Boris Johnson would sell the NHS to Donald Trump, was ripped off the website.A statement from Reddit at the time said: We were recently made aware of a post on Reddit that included leaked documents from the UK.We investigated this account and the accounts connected to it, and today we believe this was part of a campaign that has been reported as originating from Russia.The Labour leader was branded a foolish pawn over the blunder.Conservative Party chairman James Cleverley blasted: Corbyn has some serious questions to answer.Is he a foolish pawn in a Russian disinformation campaign, or did he know where the leaked documents came from Analysts at the time claimed the papers, waved by Mr Corbyn at an election rally, bore the hallmarks of a Russian disinformation campaign called Secondary Infektion.Labour were quick to pounce on the contents of the papers, claiming they revealed the plot against our NHS.Experts previously raised fears over the origin of the documents.Ben Nimmo, head of investigations at media analytics outfit Graphika, said: “It’s on the same set of websites, it’s using the same types of accounts and making the same language errors.It’s either the Russian operation or someone trying hard to look like it.”Ousted MP and Corbynite Laura Pidcock even got into a row with Skys Kay Burley over the documents, refusing five times to say whether the partys leaked NHS dossier came from Russia.The then shadow secretary of state for employment rights got into a spat with the journalistdays after Jeremy Corbyn claimed hed found evidence that the NHS would be up for sale in a series of papers.The original Reddit posting was uploaded on October  but was little known until Mr Corbyn unveiled it at a highly trailed campaign event.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: johnny depp bruise birthday bust up amber heard trial
story: The -year-old has claimed Heard, , was the one who abused him during their relationship.And the stars security guard today told the High Court he had taken a photograph of Depp with a mark below his eye after an alleged bust-up with Heard after her LA birthday in April .Sean Bett today told the court: He had been at a business meeting and was running late for the party. Later on in the evening, I was called by Mr Depp and I then drove him home to another one of his properties. He had told me that Ms Heard had sought to argue with him and had punched him causing him to sustain visible injury.The High Court heard today:The High Court previously heard Depp had been late to the event celebrating his wes birthday as he had just found out he had lost million.Depp is alleged to have hurled a magnum of champagne at Heard, grabbed her hair and threw her on their bed, before leaving a note saying “Happy f***ing birthday”.But Depp claimed Heard had attacked him — before leaving a poo in his bed.A photograph of Heard at Coachella the weekend after her th birthday party was later shown to the court, with the star posing with pals including her sister Whitney and io Tillett Wright.Security guard Starling Jenkins told the court: During the weekend, I heard Amber frequently express her anger that Johnny did not come to her birthday party on April , but she did not say one thing or make any innuendos about allegations of domestic violence.Photographs were today shown to the court of Depp with a mark on his cheek after the fight in April - one of the last alleged bust-ups between the couple before their orce. There was confusion over the picture after Depps team submitted two very similar pictures, one dated March  and the other April .The court was told Heard had admitted to injuring Depp in March  - saying it had been to defend her sister.The actor’s bodyguard recounted another alleged incident between the couple, saying he went into the couple’s home in May  after hearing the Aquaman actress shouting “at the top of her lungs”.He said: “When we entered, we saw Mr Depp standing approximately  feet away from Ms Heard, who was standing by the couch.“As soon as Ms Heard noticed that we had entered the room, she looked very surprised her demeanour then changed and she pointed at Mr Depp and screamed to us words to the effect of: ‘If he hits me one more time, I am calling the police’.”However he claimed he could not see any injuries on the actress.The bodyguard claimed there had been a recurring cycle that would see Heard would abuse the Hollywood star, who would then remove himself from the situation.And he said he would see arguments between the couple, with Depp often asking him to drive Heard home because he would “feel bad” after the rows.Mr Bett said on the drive home the actress would cry and say home much she loved Depp.Photographs were also shown to the court, taken by Mr Bett, which allegedly show injuries to Depps nose after an incident in December .He told the court: There was also redness on the side of his cheek. title: suspicious package bromley
story: Officers raced to the scene near Bromley North Station, South East London following reports of a suspicious package at about .pm this afternoon.A source told MyLondon that the suspicious package was found in a law firm office on London Road.We were told by the emergency services that an unidentiable white powdered substance was found in our office... it was contained within a package from a department at a high security prison, the source reportedly said.A Met Police spokesman refused to comment on the claim but said the package was found at a commercial premises.Police have also received reports that two people are feeling unwell at the scene.One home has been evacuated and road closures remain in place.The London Ambulance service have deployed their hazardous area response teams.A spokeswoman from the London Fire Brigade said teams from Bromley, Beckenham and Lewisham are there.The Met Police, the London Ambulance Service and the London Fire Brigade remain at the scene. title: brits work from home patrick vallance
story: As revealed by The Sun, the Prime Minister will tomorrow tell the nation it is once again safe to use public transport and head back into workplaces.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesThe government is increasingly concerned that working from home, which has turned Britains cities into ghost towns, will have a devastating long term impact on the economy.But in another day of mixed messages, Sir Patrick Vallance, the Chief Scientic Adviser, appeared to directly contradict Downing Street.Speaking to MPs, Sir Patrick said he could see “absolutely no reason” why millions of Brits should not continue to work from home to limit the spread of Covid-. Addressing the Common’s Science and Technology Committee, he said other Government advisers shared his concerns. Sir Patrick said: “My view on this and I think this is a view shared by SAGE, is that were still at a time when distancing measures are important.“And of the ious distancing measures, working from home for many companies remains a perfectly good option because its easy to do.WHAT WE KNOW SO FAR:“A number of companies think its actually not detrimental to productivity, and in that situation, there’s absolutely no reason I can see to change it.”But Sir Patrick was not finished there. He also delivered a scathing assessment on the timing of the UKs lockdown and Number s overall handling of the deadly pandemic.He said lockdown measures should have been in place a week earlier while the outcome of the coronavirus “has not been good for the UK.”Mr Johnson enforced the countrys lockdown restrictions on March . title: human skeletons found edinburgh tram expansion leith
story: Archaeologists have discovered ten bodies so far in medieval graves dating from  and  outside South Leith Parish Church, before work begins to expand trams to Newhaven.Previous investigations have shown that in the medieval period the churchs graveyard extended across the road with graves surviving beneath the current road surface.After the bodies have been excavated the remains will be undergo examination and analysis that will reveal information on the origins, health, diseases and diet of the people of medieval Leith.Council archaeologist John Lawson said: The historic port and town of Leith is one of Scotlands most signicant urban archaeological sites with evidence of occupation going back over  years.Although only just started, the excavations by our team have already provided important new evidence regarding the history of the graveyard and earlier town with the discovery of what we believe are the remains of its original medieval graveyard wall.It is hoped that further new discoveries will be made and that we will learn important new evidence for the lives of Leiths medieval inhabitants so that we can tell their story to modern Leithers.Depute leader Cammy Day said: This is an extremely fascinating, essential part of the broader project to bring the tram to Newhaven, shedding some light on centuries of history here in Leith.Its crucial that we conserve the remains found here, and a team of archaeologists are carrying out the painstaking job of doing this.Whats more, further examination of the excavated graves will give us an invaluable glimpse into the lives of Leithers past.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. story: The -year-old was filmed in Syria having ditched her Islamic dress and instead donning western clothes including jeans, a shirt and a blue hat.Images were taken from footage as she walked away refusing to speak with ITV News, who approached her in Camp Roj in the northern part of the war-torn country. The former schoolgirl, one of three Bethnal Green girls to leave Britain in  to join ISIS, won a bombshell legal ruling to be allowed back to the UK to challenge her revoked British citizenship.Then-Home Secretary Sajid Javid stripped her of her citizenship on national security grounds after Times journalist Anthony Lloyd found her nine months pregnant last February.However, upon herto Britain Begum is likely to be arrested and questioned before facing trial on terror-related charges, reports the Mirror She was seen then wearing full black Islamic dress and burka, having lost her baby boy just weeks after he was born.The bombshell ruling could now open the door for other ISIS brides and fighters to make similar audacious bids toto Britain.And her brother-in-law and electrician Mohammed Rahman said today he is stuck between a rock and a hard place.He said: She’s part of my extended family. sitting with Lady Justice King and Lord Justice Singh - said: Fairness and justice must, on the facts of this case, outweigh the national security concerns, so that the leave to enter appeals should be allowed.The Court of Appeal ruled: The only way in which she can have a fair and effective appeal is to be permitted to come into the United Kingdom to pursue her appeal.Begum was one of three east London schoolgirls who travelled to Syria in  to join ISIS.After marrying an ISIS fighter and sewing terrorists into suicide vests, she was found pregnant more than three years later in a Syrian refugee camp - evenshe fails to get citizenship back.Sajid Javid warned: Most critically, allowing her and indeed other terrorists back into the UK to pursue an appeal would create a real security risk that cannot be fully mitigated, even with the ersion of signicant resources.If Ms Begum does come to this country it will prove impossible to remove her.Following the ruling a Home Office spokesperson said: “This is a very disappointing decision by the Court. story: Since coronavirus became part of our lives in March, none of us has been able to escape this affliction of unease.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesBut it’s a dficult mood to unpick. title: uk may have herd immunity prevent second coronavirus wave scientists
story: While super-spreaders infect many, it appears some people are effectively super-blockers and enjoy natural resistance to the killer bug, say Oxford University boffins.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesThe scientists have written about host resistance to the new virus and a possibly lower threshold of herd immunity needed to fend off further devastating Covid- outbreaks.Their paper, published on Medrxiv, says that it is widely believed the threshold needed to enjoy herd immunity against the new disease is more than  per cent.But, its research suggests thatjust  per cent of the UKs population has in-built resistance to Covid-, a second wave is not inevitable.Herd immunity refers to where enough people in a population have immunity to an infection to be able to effectively stop that disease from spreading.For herd immunity, it doesn’t matter whether the protection comes from vaccination, or from people having had the disease. The crucial thing is that they are immune.The Oxford Uni study suggests the epidemiological limit to reach herd immunity may be greatly reduceda fraction of the population is unable to transmit the virus.This is feasible, they add,people have inbuilt resistance or cross-protection from exposure to seasonal coronaviruses.The report says: Signicant reductions in expected mortality can also be seen in settings where a fraction of the population is resistant to infection.Results suggest that sufficient herd-immunity may already be in place to substantially mitigate a potential second wave, the researchers add.It has been evident from the outset that the risk of severe disease and death from Covid- is not unormly distributed across all age classes.The bulk of deaths among the over  million cases reported worldwide are occurring among older age classes and those with [pre-existing conditions].“It is further becoming clear that risk of infection is also not unormly distributed across the population, the reports says.Scientists at Oxford point to those managing to fend off the virus as having high ing immunity.And,antibodies to the disease are built up in - per cent of the population, this is entirely compatible with local levels of immunity having approached or even exceeded the herd immunity threshold.In which case the risk and scale of resurgence is lower than currently perceived, say the researchers.Immunity to the bug has been hitting headlines for months, with Kings College research saying antibody responses to the killer bug “can be detected in most infected iniduals - days following the onset of Covid- symptoms”.It investigated samples from  coronavirus patients,  days after they had been diagnosed with Covid-.Worryingly, Kings Colleges study found that immunity to fight coronavirus might disappear only three months after infection.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: brexit latest news updates eu uk today brussels live
story: It comes two days after a furious exchanges in the House of Commons regarding the future of Brexit - with the Scottish National Party accused by the government of stirring up ision as they debated an extension to the transition period beyond . Meanwhile, Labour MPs were accused of dodging the Brexit debate after their backbenchers failed to show in the Commons.Follow our live blog below for all the latest news and updates.Thats all from us this evening, but well be back with the latest on Brexit from am.EU members are set to meet for face to face talks on Friday and Saturday for the first time since the virtually the entire bloc went into lockdown in March.Member states are seeking to agree a compromise on a propose stimulus to kickstart economic growth, which has been devastated by the coronavirus pandemic.But securing a deal will not be easy, with the possibility of a Hungarian veto and Dutch opposition among the threats to an agreement. Among the proposals that have proved controversial are a coronavirus recovery fund worth around € billion, aimed at helping economies in southern Europe recover from the crisis.#For the markets, for the general image of the European Union, for the political message towards the member states and towards our citizens, it would be fantasticwe reached an agreement,# Croatian Prime Minister Andrej Plenkovic said late on Thursday.But with major dferences persisting on the scale and scope of recovery funding, as well as on the budget, he added: #Its never certain whether an agreement will be finalised, or not.#Countries high in debt, such as Italy and Spain, are calling for recovery financing to come in free grants rather than repayable loans. However, this has met criticism from more #frugal# northern states such as Denmark and the Netherlands, who are demanding a smaller overall package and economic reforms as a condition of securing the loans. Ms Patel also announced the beefed-up measures for Border Force and immigration officials today.The Government revealed even criminals not sentenced to  months face being booted out of Britain.It said: #Those already in the UK who are sentenced to  months or more in prison must be considered for deportation.#Where the -month criminality deportation threshold is not met, a foreign criminal will still be considered for deportation where it is conducive to the public good, including where they have serious or persistent criminality.#The change means criminals from the European Union are treated the same as currently happens to those from non-EU countries.Priti Patel has revealed the UKs new points based immigration system, outlining a #firm but fair# approach to immigration from .The new plans, promised for years since Britain voted to leave the EU back in , will see freedom of movement scrapped in favour of an Australian-style points-based scheme.Under the new system, foreign nationals applying to come to the UK for work purposes will have to meet certain criteria.It will assign points for specic skills, qualications, salaries or professions, and visas will only be awarded to those who gain enough points.The minimum requirements will include having a job offer from an approved sponsor that suits their skill level and being able to speak English.Foreign nationals wishing to come to the UK for work purposes will need to score  points to successfully apply for an online “e-visa”.If an applicant meets the criteria of the minimum requirements, they will be awarded  points.But to score above this threshold they will have to meet other criteria based on salary, seeking to work in a sector with a recognised labour shortage or a having a PhD.The government has started work on a huge post-Brexit lorry park in Ashford, Kent to help deal with possible trade frictions after the end of the transition period.There are growing concerns the site could be used as a giant car park for thousands of lorries waiting to travel to the continent.KentOnline reports that locals were finally sent details confirming the details of the site yesterday.Addressing concerned residents, MP Rachel McClean wrote: “We are aware you will have seen reports over the weekend concerning the governments interest in the site in Sevington.“We sincerely apologise that information on this matter made its way into the press before we were able to communicate with you directly.“We have not been able to inform you of our interest in the site before now for reasons of commercial confidentiality.”Manufacturers have warned that #red wall# seats # former Labour heartland constituencies won by the Tories at the last election # could be hit hard by a no-deal Brexit.Make UK, the manufacturers organisation, claimed that leaving without a deal in place could be #fatal# for the industry.Stephen Phipson, chief executive of Make UK, said: “Should the UK fail to reach a comprehensive trade agreement with the EU then those regions with a high concentration of manufacturing and a dependence on Europe as a major market will suffer a triple hit given the impact of Covid-. For some companies the combination may prove fatal.”He added: “We are now at a tipping point in how we build a recovery and a post-Covid economy. If that means tearing up the rule book on adopting a new approach to policy then so be it, nothing should be off the table.”We have already reported how Westminster has drawn up plans for a new #internal market# which it says is necessary to ensure seamless trade between England, Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland.But Ian Blackford of the SNP had strong words today for the proposed plan, labelling it a #con trick#. He said: #This Tory con trick is a botched attempt to disguise a blatant power grab on the Scottish Parliament, which could see Westminster block Scotland from taking action in devolved areas.#People in Scotland will not be fooled. Despite the smoke and mirrors, none of the so-called new powers outlined by the Tory Government are new # all are already devolved.#Crucially, the mechanism proposed would enable Westminster to override Scotlands democratic decisions and impose its own policies, such as lower standards for food safety, animal and plant health, and environmental protections.#Mr Blackford added that it represented the #biggest threat to devolution since the Scottish Parliament was reconvened in .#— Micheál MartinJuly , The European Court of Justice has today banned Privacy Shield, which is a data-sharing agreement between the EU and the US. But it has been warned that this could impact British businesses after the transition period.Daniel Tozer, head of data at law firm Harbottle and Lewis, told the : #This judgement raises questions about the UK’s ability to be awarded data protection ‘adequacy’  by the EU, given the UK’s own surveillance laws and its membership of the Five Eyes programme.#Scottish First Minister Nicola Sturgeon said the SNPs opposition to the Governments proposed post-Brexit regulatory framework was #about not wanting to see the UK Government ride roughshod over the powers of the Scottish Parliament#.According to Ms Sturgeon, the proposals #effectively would allow the UK Government to decide issues of food standards or consumer standards, environmental standards that right now are decisions for the Scottish Parliament#.She added: #Retrospectively that could have meant the Scottish Parliament not being able to legislate for minimum pricing for alcohol, and not being able to stop GM crops.#These are important issues of principle and it is about the ability of democratically elected Parliament of Scotland to take decisions in the powers we have, based on what we consider to be right for Scotland.#Northern Irelands deputy first minister says that she had productive discussions with Irish taoiseach Micheal Martin at Stormont today on the future of both economies.She said: #We spoke about the potential implications of Brexit and the pressing concerns this raises.#I set out the need to work together to protect the needs and interests of people and businesses across this island.#The new Irish taoiseach Micheal Martin visited Belfast today for meetings with Stormont First Minister Arlene Foster and Deputy First Minister Michelle ONeill.Among the key issues discussed included Brexit, with the future of the Irish border still being figured out. Ms ONeill said: #It is now six months since the restoration of the Executive and I made clear to Micheal that we must see delivery of all the Irish Governments commitments in New Decade, New Approach.#I look forward to working on a north-south basis to ensure those crucial funding and practical commitments are fulfilled as soon as possible.#The New Decade, New Approach agreement, signed on  January , restored the government of the Northern Ireland executive after a three-year hiatus.The Welsh government has warned Downing Street not to impose new post-Brexit rules without their consent. It comes as Business secretary Alok Sharma promised a #seamless UK internal market# after the end of the transition period # when the devolved administrations will see new powers ed. But a spokesperson for the Welsh government has said these systems must have #independent oversight#. They told the BBC: #Any new system must have independent oversight and dispute resolution.#Unfortunately, the UK government has not managed to share the paper with us, and Welsh ministers have had no recent discussions with the UK government on these issues.#Any attempt to unilaterally impose a system will be deeply damaging.#British firms have started stockpiling goods as they fear the UK could leave the European Union without a deal.A number of listed companies have said they are taking measures to store supplies and review plans in case of border disruption should a deal not be reached, the Financial Times reports.Should a no-deal outcome become reality there are worries about the cost of extra red tape, as well as strict border checks on goods.Lindsey Ruth, chief executive of Electrocomponents, said: “Our priority is continuity of supply and maintaining [a] world class customer experience.#During the coronavirus pandemic Wales gave England more than  million items of personal protective equipment, the countrys health minister has revealed.Mutual aid agreements in place with Westminster, Holyrood and Stormont saw nearly  million items of PPE, such as facemasks, gloves, visors and gowns, given to England, Scotland and Northern Ireland.Wales had received . million items of PPE from those countries in .Image: GettyPost-Brexit arrangements which the UK Government insists will bring new powers to Scotland pose the #biggest threat to devolution# since Holyrood was established, the SNPs Westminster leader has said.Ian Blackford described plans to create a new #internal market# across the UK once the Brexit transition period ends as a #blatant power grab# from Westminster.Cabinet Office minister Michael Gove has insisted a #a power surge is occurring# which will see #scores of new powers# transferred to the Scottish Parliament.UK ministers have said theof powers to the UK from Brussels after December , when the transition period ends, will see the Northern Ireland administration receive responsibility in  of the  areas, Scotland in  and Wales in .A big story this afternoon – hackers linked to the Russian intelligence agencies are targeting British scientists seeking to develop a coronavirus vaccine, the National Cyber Security Centrehas warned.In a joint statement with the US National Security Agency and the Canadian Communication Security Establishment, the NCSC said the attacks were part of a global campaign by the group known as APT to steal the secrets of vaccine research.NCSC director of operations Paul Chichester said: “We condemn these despicable attacks against those doing vital work to combat the coronavirus pandemic.”He said Brits, the US and Canadians believe APT – also known as the Dukes or Cozy Bear – was “almost certainly” operating as part of the Russian intelligence services.Brits heading abroad next year may be left confused regarding their holidays, with the UK leaving the EU Customs Union and Single Market on January , .Brits travelling to Europe after Brexit should be aware that theres new advice around everything from passports and visas to EHIC and driving licences.You can still book holidays until the end of the year without any changes taking place – flights, ferries, cruises, Eurostar, Eurotunnel, and bus and coach services are not yet affected by Brexit.Holidays will still go ahead as usual in  as well, but may require additional travel documents and rules.New passport rules will apply when the transition period ends on January .After the transition period, Brits may need an additional  months on their documents, which means you should double-check whether you need a new passport before you travel.Image: GettyA leaked document on UK-US trade used by Jeremy Corbyn during the  general election was sourced from Russian hackers, foreign secretary Dominic Raab has said today.The papers, which discussed a potential deal, were used by the opposition leader as evidence the NHS will be #on the table# in talks on a post-Brexit trade deal with the US.There is no suggestion Mr Corbyn knew the report had been widely circulated online by actors working on behalf of Moscow.Areas of the UK that voted to leave the EU have suffered the biggest economic hit since the  referendum, according to new research reported by the Financial Times.The study from the Centre for Competitive Advantage in the Global Economy at Warwick University suggests Brexit is likely to further complicate efforts to level up underperforming regions.Research found that the parts of the UK with high levels of low-skilled and manufacturing employment have underperformed most since . These areas also heavily voted Leave in the EU referendum.Many of the districts have unusually high levels of furloughed workers, raising the prospect that they could also be hardest hit by the coronavirus recession. A Welsh Government spokesman has released a statement after officials claimed the UK Government was forcing new post-Brexit rules through without consultation.The spokesman said: #We support having rules across the UK to regulate the internal market, but these rules must be agreed between the four Governments in the UK, each of which has their own responsibility for economic development.#Any new system must have independent oversight and dispute resolution.#Unfortunately, the UK Government has not managed to share the Paper with us, and Welsh Ministers have had no recent discussions with the UK Government on these issues.#But UK Business Secretary Alok Sharma said there had been discussions with the Welsh Government on #common frameworks# and ministers #have known the direction of travel#.The Welsh Government has warned that forcing post-Brexit trading rules on Wales without its consent would be #deeply damaging#.Plans for a new #internal market# drawn up by Westminster to ensure seamless trade between England, Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland were not shared with Welsh ministers before being announced, it said.Measures that were previously regulated by the European Union willto the UK at the end of the year when the transition period expires, with the UK Government saying it would see Northern Ireland receive responsibility in  of the  areas, Scotland in  and Wales in .As this could lead to dferent regulatory regimes in the UK, Westminster has drawn up plans for the #internal market# to make sure set regulations are recognised across the nations, ensuring seamless trade between them.But on Thursday, the Welsh Government said the changes had to be agreed between all the devolved administrations, and that ministers in Cardf Bay have so far had no discussions with those in Westminster.Former prime minister Tony Blair has said Boris Johnson should delay Brexit by a year to avoid a #disastrous no deal#.A study, commissioned by the Tony Blair Institute, says it would be a “grave mistake” for Britain not to agree a delay at the same time it faces a “deep recession” due to the coronavirus crisis.The report said there is a #landing zone for sensible compromise# between the UK and EU to agree on a deal.More on plans for that lorry park in Kent.Critics of the scheme fear the -acre site near Ashford will be used as a giant car park for thousands of lorries waiting to travel to the continent.In a letter to residents on Wednesday, transport minister Rachel Maclean confirmed the Department for Transport had purchased the land and was now planning #two primary uses# for the site.She said: #First, government departments envisage using it as a permanent site for facilities related to future border processes, notably HMRCand Defra .#Second, the site may also be used as a contingency lorry holding area for the particular, foreseeable risk of signicant disruption at the end of the transition period.#Ms Maclean said there was #no intention# to develop the site as a permanent lorry holding facility for use in the event of #cross-Channel disruption#.Image: London News PicturesMichael Gove has sought to reassure MPs amid concerns about the arrangements for the flow of goods from Europe to the UK at the end of the Brexit transition period.During Cabinet Office questions, Labour former minister Hilary Benn raised the issue of how many sites in Kent are being considered for the building of infrastructure to check goods leaving the UK.These so-called lorry parks have been met with criticism from the MP for Kent.Mr Benn said: #How many sites in Kent is [Mr Gove] looking at to put infrastructure on, and, of those sites, how many will be to check the paperwork of goods leaving the UK and how many will be to check goods coming in to the UK #Mr Gove, the Chancellor of the Duchy of Lancaster, replied: #Well, there are five sites that we were looking at and indeed yesterday the Department for Transport confirmed that a site at Ashford has been secured.#Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: leicester lockdown lifted hancock
story: Sir Peter Soulsby slammed Health Secretary Matt Hancocks decision to keep some restrictions in force across the Labour-run city and Liberal Democrat-controlled Oadby and Wigston.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesMr Hancock announced that schools and some shops will reopen from July  in the city which had been hit with a surge in Covid- cases.But Sir Peter accused the government of penalising Leicesters economy by not lting restrictions further.He said: They have chosen to focus on the city geographical area - effectively the area of the county that votes Labour and thats just scandalous.If they were going to alter the boundary, they should have gone down to the area that they now know where the virus is.They have left two areas in there - one that has a Liberal Democrat council, the other that has a Labour mayor.The fact is they have focused in a way that is clearly party political and thats not a way to deal with the virus.They are prepared not just to penalise this city, but also to penalise its economy.”Mr Hancock said tonight that the local city-wide lockdown would be partially lted from July , but other measures would stay in place.The seven day infection rate is now  per , people - down from  per ,.Mr Hancock said testing had doubled in the city, but stressed it was too soon to lt all the vital measures to control the spread.He chaired several meetings today to decide on the latest moves.And he stressed that a more targeted local area would now be the focus of the local lockdown.The rules will only apply to Oadby and Wigston area of Leicestershire from next Friday - as well as the city of Leicester itself.Mr Hancock said this evening in the House of Commons: We are now in a position to relax some, but not all, of the measures.From July  we will remove restrictions on schools and early years childcare, taking a more targeted approach to non-essential retail.Travel restrictions will remain and people will still only be able to have gatherings with six people. And those measures introduced on the fourth of July will also not apply, he added.However, most schools in Leicester have already broken up for the summer break.The measures would be reviewed again in two weeks to seemore progress has been made, and more rules can be relaxed.He also confirmed that some types of coronavirus swab tests would stop being used for the meantime as the Government assesses their safety.Some were not up to the usual high standards, the health secretary says - but stressed that there is no evidence of harm or impact on test results.The Health Secretary said: I hope these careful easing of restrictions will provide some comfort to the people of Leicester and Leciestershire.I say this directly to the people... I pay tribute to you. You have all shown respect for one another.I understand this hasnt been easy.There is still a lot to do and the public health messages remain critical.Please do not lose your resolve. The sooner we get this virus under control, the sooner we can restore le in Leicester.The city was the first in the UK to be put back into lockdown last month after a spike in cases.Testing centres swooped on the city and people were encouraged to stay home. Shops were shut up again and pubs and restaurants did not open on July  as in the rest of the country.A Department of Health and Social Care spokesperson said today: As this data confirms, coronavirus cases in Leicester were signicantly higher than other parts of the country – and we took clear and decisive action to save lives.“We are working closely with the local authorities to ensure that these measures are only in place as long as is necessary, and we will set out the next steps by  July.”The Government has stressed that data has been provided to the Directors of Public Health throughout the incident.The lockdown currently covers the city of Leicester as well as surrounding areas including Birstall, Beaumont Leys, Glenfield and South Wigston. It has been suggested that families living in closer quarters, combined with a higher population of people whose English is a second language, may have contributed to the spike in cases.Workers in cramped clothing factories have also been blamed, with Police and the National Crime Agency investigating possible links to modern slavery.But Sir Peter told Sky News there is no evidence whatsoever to show coronavirus was being transmitted in clothing factories.Theres nothing in the data that suggests it is transmitting in places of work, he said.Mr Hancock revealed flare-ups are being swtly and silently dealt with.He said more than  local actions are being taken across the country each week.Professor Jonathan Van-Tam told the BBC that data published on Saturday showed the city is really quite an outlier compared with anywhere  in the country.Mr Van-Tam told the BBC: The situation has improved but it needs to go further.He said that, while it would not be his decision to end the lockdown, doing so cant be rushed.Pressed on whether Leicesters lockdown is likely to be lted, Mr Van-Tam said: With any of these things, usually the way that one approaches them from a public health perspective is to take a phased approach.Normally you dont just go from having the brakes on heavily to just taking the brakes off completely.I think thats a reasonable expectation to set.To receive The Sun’s Coronavirus title: jeremy corbyn statement russia election
story: The ex-Labour boss defended using the genuine leaked dossier on UK-US trade talks, and claimed the accusations was an attempt to ert attention away from them.The then Labour leader had tried to use the leaked NHS documents used to smear the Tories ahead of his disastrous election result.The Government have today claimed that the dossier held up by Mr Corbyn during the election campaign - was amplied by Russians.It claimed Russian actors were involved in the spread of the document.Its not clear who leaked it and how - but this is now subject to a criminal investigation.The documents - which Mr Corbyn claimed was proof Boris wanted to sell off the NHS in a trade deal but offered no evidence - were first uploaded onto the internet site Reddit in October, but got no attention.Russian actors then sought to promote them further and get more media attention to try and interfere in the UKs election, the Government said.Mr Corbyn said in a statement this evening: The documents we revealed during the general election about the danger of a Trump trade deal for our NHS were genuine - as is the threat of a £ million a week higher drugs bill.The Tories want to distract from the damage a Trump trade deal would do to our NHS by continuing to push the bogus claim Labour received Russian support. Today’s government claim is an attempt to ert attention from the threat to the NHS and the Tory party links to Russian oligarchs expected to be revealed in the long-buried parliamentary Russia report.The former Labour boss refused to answer questions from journalists outside his home in North London this afternoon.Mr Corbyn was asked by a journalist: Mr Corbyn, Do you have anything to say about Russian disruption  Were you complicit Did you help those who attacked our election, Mr Corbyn Mr Corbyn then shut the gate and said: Goodbye.The reporter continued: Do you have anything to say at all, Mr Corbyn, about whats happened today Do you regret whats happened Are you complicit with Russian interference in our elections, Mr Corbyn Would you do it again, Mr Corbyn Do you have anything to add about what happened, Mr Corbyn Do you regret your actions, Mr Corbyn, do you regret taking that document The ex-Labour leader then shut the door after wheeling his bike inside, followed with another goodbye to the reporter.The Government said today:The dossier of leaked minutes from trade talks, which Mr Corbyn claimed was evidence Boris Johnson would sell the NHS to Donald Trump, was ripped off the website.Analysts at the time claimed the papers, waved by Mr Corbyn at an election rally, bore the hallmarks of a Russian disinformation campaign called Secondary Infektion.Mr Corbyn has been repeatedly accused of being soft on Russia, even refusing to blame them for the Salisbury Novichok attack.The ousted hard left Labour leader would only go as far as saying “the evidence points strongly” to the Kremlin.In March last year Mr Corbyn sparked a furious backlash after warning Theresa May against “rushing way ahead of the evidence” on Salisbury.His spokesman at the time said memories of the Iraqi “dodgy” dossier meant it was “problematic” to accept the Government’s position.Labour today distanced themselves from Russia.A spokesman said: “We condemn any attempt by Russia..to interfere in our country’s democratic processes.Labour stands ready to work cross-party to protect our nation’s security.A senior Russian politician said today that allegations that Russia tried to meddle in the  General Election are anti-Russian nonsense which undermine UK-Russia relations and the UKs own authority.The Russian Foreign Ministry added: “The statement is so foggy and contradictory that it is almost impossible to understand it.If it’s inappropriate to say something then dont say it. If you say it, produce the facts”.The online forum Reddit confirmed the leak was linked to the Kremlin in December last year.It came as Vladimir Putins Russia was today blamed for being behind repeated cyber attacks to try and steal a coronavirus vaccine from Britain.The UK has been able to point the finger at Russia for the very first time in explosive claims President Putin knew about attacks on Britains coronavirus vaccine project.A joint operation with the US and Canada has uncovered a malicious campaign to steal information uncovered by Britains top scientists on coronavirus with targeted attacks since March.No said today they believe the attacks came from a group known at APT - part of the Russian intelligence service.The clandestine group of hackers is also known as “the Dukes” or “Cozy Bear”.The PMs official spokesman said today: The attacks which are taking place against scientists and others doing vital work to combat coronavirus are despicable.Working with our allies, we will call out those who seek to do us harm in cyber space and hold them to account.Heres what we know about the attacks:The National Cyber Security Centre have thrown every protection they have at Britains vaccination projects to keep them safe from attempts to steal information.British research projects are at the forefront of the effort to find a vaccine with scientists at Oxford University and Imperial University London leading the charge to prevent thousands more from dying.Britain is expected to publish a long-delayed report into Russian influence in British politics next week.To receive The Sun’s Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.To follow us on Facebook, simply ‘Like’ our Coronavirus page.Get Britain’s best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day – find out more.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailCoronavirus tests given to thousands of Brits and supplied by a firm which has donated £, to the Conservative Party were pulled last night over safety fears.Care homes in England were ordered by the DHSC to halt using the testing kit produced by Randox Laboratories, on the grounds that they “may not meet our required safety standards for coronavirus testing”.Randox Laboratories was awarded the £ million contract by the Department for Health and Social Carein May after a non-competetive bidding process. The firm has donated a total of £, to the party since April , according to the Electoral Commission. The most recent donation, of £, was made to the party in September . The firm has also employed Owen Paterson, a Tory MP and former minister, as an advisor since , and is paid £, a year. The Mirror understands red flags were raised about the aposCEapos safety stamps on the Chinese-made tests supplied by Randox. Physical inspection of the tests led to questions about the sterility of the swabs. Health Secretary Matt Hancock said Clinical advice is that thereaposs no evidence of any harm, the test results are not affected, there is no evidence of any issues with our other test swabs and there is no impact on access to testing. In a statement issued yesterday, the Department of Health said: “As a precautionary measure and while we investigate further, NHS Test and Trace are requesting that all settings pause the use of Randox test kits with immediate effect and until further notice.” Randox, which described its system as part of the “cornerstone of Government testing across the UK”, was awarded the contract in May as the Government was racing to meet its target of , tests per day. Grilling Mr Hancock in the House of Commons on Thursday evening, shadow Health Secretary Jon Ashworth questioned the awarding of the contract which he said was “given to Randox without any competitive tender”.  The firm, based in County Antrim, posted on its website in June: “Our test was adopted by the NHS and Public Health England and forms the cornerstone of Government testing across the UK. Using the Randox-patented Biochip Array Technology, the most-comprehensive multiplex PCR  on the market.” As a result of the recall of the kits, a number of testing sites have also been forced to suspend all activity until further notice. This afternoon Wirral Council announced that it had closed down the Bidston Coronavirus Testing Site near Birkenhead “for precautionary reasons, due to a safety recall issued by the Government on Randox test kits”. The Department for Health and Social Care said there wasnapost enough time to perform a full procurement contest because of the short notice in ramping up coronavirus testing.A spokesperson said:   “The speed at which we have increased our testing capacity is unprecedented and a real success made possible by teamwork between the Government and key partners.“In a matter of weeks we have engineered the largest ever expansion of British diagnostic capability - scaling up a nationwide network of drive-in testing sites, introducing home testing, deploying mobile testing units operated by Armed Forces personnel, building three new ‘mega labs’ to analyse test samples, and more than doubling the capacity of the NHS and Public Health England laboratories.”

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid Email Councils are to be given new powers so they can impose shut downs quicker in the event of coronavirus outbreaks, according to reports.The lightning lockdowns plan will reportedly allow local authorities to shut pubs and cafés without having to first get the green-light from the Government. It could also mean bans on weddings and other large gatherings at short notice.A Government health source told The Sun: Councils will be able to impose lighting lockdowns where they see fit.Boris Johnson is set update his road map to help Britain bounce back from the pandemic at a Downing Street press conference on Friday.For updates on coronavirus, follow our live blog HERE.  As well as the powers for councils, the PM is set commit to a new target of reaching the capacity for , coronavirus tests a day by November. The NHS will be granted an extra £ billion in funding to prepare for a second wave. In the wake of a dire warning of the consequences of Covid- rebounding, No said the funding will allow extra hospital capacity while allowing routine treatments and procedures to continue.  The funding for the NHS in England will allow private hospital capacity to be used and for Nightingale hospitals to be maintained until the end of March. It comes after a report commissioned by the Governmentaposs chief scientic adviser, Sir Patrick Vallance, warned there could be , hospital deaths in a reasonable worst-case scenario. Winter always places a great strain on the health service, but there are concerns a resurgence of the virus during the annual flu season could be crippling.  A Government spokesperson said the NHS must be battle ready for winter. Tomorrow, he will set out a broad package of measures to protect against both a possible second wave, and to ease winter pressures and keep the public safe. The spokesman said the immediate funding for England was new and not previously allocated, while expenditure will be set out for the devolved nations in due course. NHS Providers, which represents NHS organisations, deputy chief executive Saffron Cordery has called for urgent clarity over what the funding will cover.  She said funding is already in place for the Nightingale hospitals and private beds, while social care is in a critical condition but the Government is yet to afford it any extra money. The British Medical Association also called for details on how the money will be used. Earlier this week Mr Johnson was warned in the report by the Academy of Medical Sciences that action must be taken now to mitigate the potential for a second peak, including scaling up the Test and Trace system.  The research said capacity for , tests per day will be needed to test iniduals as they show symptoms of either Covid- or flu. The latest Government figures say capacity stood at nearly ,, but Mr Johnson will commit to increase this to half a million by the end of October to bolster Test and Trace. Health Secretary Matt Hancock has already announced plans for the biggest flu vaccination programme in history, with eligibility for free injections likely to be extended. Non-urgent operations were suspended to free up hospital beds as the UK was plunged into a lockdown during the first wave. But Downing Street says the new plans to be announced by the PM will allow them to go ahead where possible as ministers target efforts on local lockdowns.
